awd_titl_txt: Charge-Spin Conversions in Helical Metals and Chiral Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
Conventional semiconductor microelectronics utilize only the charge of electrons for logic operations. It has been demonstrated that harnessing the spin of electrons can not only lead to enhanced performance such as dramatic reduction in power consumption but also produce fundamentally new functionalities such as nonvolatility and reconfigurable logics. An essential ingredient of spin-based semiconductor electronics is the creation of electron populations and currents with well-defined spin orientations, i.e., spin polarization, in a nonmagnetic semiconductor. This project aims to generate, control, and detect polarized spins in semiconductors through pure electrical means, and in some cases without even using any magnetic material. One way is by driving an electric current through the surface of a topological insulator, where the electron velocity and spin are always locked in orthogonal directions; the other is by pushing electrons through a chiral medium, which can be a monolayer of chiral organic molecules or inorganic materials with inherent chiral crystal structures. Practically, the research may lead to new paradigms of spintronics devices free of magnetic materials. At the fundamental level, they offer ideal platforms for studying microscopic mechanisms of charge-spin conversions due to structural chirality and electronic interactions. The project also presents an invaluable combination of basic science research and technology development, an effective venue for preparing graduate students for careers in academia and industry.

Technical Abstract:
This project is aimed at the generation, control, and detection of polarized spins in semiconductors through pure electrical means, and in some cases without using any magnetic material. The project has two distinct research thrusts, which share a common objective of addressing the manifestations and microscopic mechanisms of charge-spin conversions due to structural chirality and electronic interactions. The two lines of research specifically target demonstrating and understanding electrical generation of spin currents from charge motion in two different systems: i) 3D strong topological insulators whose surface states exhibit helical spin textures in momentum space and, ii) materials with intrinsic structural chirality in real space. In the first system, the research introduces photocurrent injection and correlated characterizations of the topological surface state, which offers high probability of deciphering the microscopic mechanism behind the current-induced spin polarization and determining its device application potentials. The study on the spin filtering effect of chiral materials is designed to produce fundamental insights on spin-dependent transport in the chiral media. The results from these physical chiral structures have broad implications in pertinent studies of emergent spin-helical states in topological materials. Practically, the research may lead to conceptually new methods of spin injection and detection, forming the basis for spintronics device platforms free of magnetic materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The interconversion of electron charge and spin, namely polarization of electron spin from charge motion and transduction of electron spin polarization as electrical signals, is at the heart of the emerging field of microelectronics known as “spintronics”. This project has focused on experimental studies of charge-spin conversions by exploiting “chirality” in real-space molecular/crystal structures or momentum-space electronic structures. Chirality, or handedness, refers to the property of broken mirror symmetry. In real space, chirality is ubiquitous, spanning systems of all length scales from subatomic to cosmic. It has been demonstrated that when an electronic charge current is passed through (nonmagnetic) molecules or crystals exhibiting structural chirality, the electrons become spin polarized; the effect has been termed chirality-induced spin selectivity, or CISS for short. In some electronic materials, certain electronic interactions “lock” the electron spin to its momentum, which manifests as distinct helical spin textures in their electronic structures. In such systems, a charge current also induces polarization of the electron spin. This project comprised two research thrusts with an overarching objective of demonstrating and understanding charge-spin conversions in two distinct chiral systems: i) Materials with intrinsic structural chirality in real space; ii) topological surface states exhibiting helical spin textures in momentum space.

In the first research thrust, we constructed “molecular junctions” comprising a monolayer of chiral oligopeptide molecules on semiconductors and a top metal electrode, and we used these robust chiral molecular electronic devices to study the CISS effect. Our unique platform provided the necessary device stability that enabled quantitative determination of how the CISS effect depends on the electric current through the chiral molecules, as well as elucidation of the key role of the electronic interaction called spin-orbit coupling in the normal metal electrode. We further demonstrated that the CISS effect is capable of producing population of polarized spins in the common semiconductor GaAs in a device structure free of any magnetic material. These results have contributed significantly to shaping the ongoing efforts of developing a viable theoretical understanding of CISS and paved the way to utilizing the CISS effect in magnet-free semiconductor spintronics.

The second research thrust focused on the characterization of the surface state of a topological insulator, particularly its potentials for charge-spin conversions and as a host for exotic electronic excitations called Majorana fermions. The latter is believed to be able to form topological qubits (quantum bits) for fault-tolerant quantum computation. Topological insulators are a class of electronic materials with an electrically insulating bulk, but conducting surfaces. In the metallic surface states, the electron spin and momentum are always locked in orthogonal directions, thus exhibiting helical spin texture in momentum space. Through several sets of targeted electrical measurements on a deliberately synthesized topological insulator, we demonstrated two characteristics considered essential in both types of applications: A topological surface state that is electrically decoupled from the bulk and an electrically transparent interface with a metal electrode. In addition to the fundamental interest of the experiments, the results provided valuable insights for optimization of charge-spin conversion and realization of the Majorana states.

The project has carried significant and diverse broader impacts. The research required in-depth understanding of fundamental semiconductor physics and magnetism, as well as proficiency in an array of experimental techniques including micro/nano fabrication, the project thus provided an excellent venue for versatile training of graduate students in preparation for careers in both industry and academia. The project has supported the Ph.D. dissertation research of five graduate students; two received Ph.D. during the grant period. This project also facilitated substantive participation of undergraduates in cutting-edge materials physics research. Five physics majors worked on the project; three successfully completed honors theses and won multiple awards based on the research they conducted. Of the students involved, one graduate student and two undergraduates were female. The PI and the graduate students also conducted a range of scientific outreach activities to the general public, especially grade 5-12 students, by leveraging heavily the outstanding outreach infrastructure at Florida State University and nearby institutions including Florida A&M University and the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory.
